transcript.content: Juan Matthews_Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Juan Matthews. Second degree murder. Wrongfully convicted. I was at the age of twenty-one when I was arrested and its twenty-six years now going on twenty-seven years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So as I said earlier, the main purpose of this is for me to learn about you and your life. So I'm going to start with your childhood if you could tell me a little bit about the folks closest to you. Who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My mother and my father. My father's name is Anthony Mark Matthews Sr. My mother's name is Eloise Matthews. Loving family. My father was in the military. He was a Navy man. Thereafter he became a longshoreman. My mother, she's a nurse, she's a secretary, and a beautiful woman.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are they still together?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No sir. My father passed away thirteen days after I got arrested on this charge.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: My goodness. So sorry.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: There's a lot heartache in this situation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about grandparents? Did you have grandparents who had a significant role in your life?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My grandmother Earnestine, Earnestine Davis. She passed away in 1996.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about siblings? Do you have siblings?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I have five brothers and five sisters.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: My goodness. Where are you in the birth order?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I'm number six because my father had children prior to my mother and father's relationship marriage and he had children before I was born.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So how many children have the same biological parents as you?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Five and five.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Five and five?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah, right down the middle. I'm the oldest of my mother and father's marriage.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay got you. If you had to pinpoint one person, an adult.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Excuse me she's calling count time do we stop for this or what?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I don't think we do. I think she knows and if so we'll just go.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Okay. I didn't check in with her so I need to, I want to make sure that she.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me if there was somebody else or the folks who were taking an interest as you were coming up? Who would you say you were closest to?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: In my family?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Or anybody?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My father most definitely. I have a lot of coaches. I played football, baseball, so I have a lot of coaches that are dear to me and most of them have passed since I've been in prison. I've kept in contact with them. Lin Lawrence comes to mind, Coach John Johnson. Those are the two main ones I can think of.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You told me you grew up in New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Not far from where I live. Which school did you go to? What were your elementary, middle, and high schools?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Elementary I went to Allen. Middle I went to Green School right across the street from my house, then I went to Woodson, then I went to Cohen and got kicked out of Cohen and went to Alcée Fortier Senior High.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alcée Fortier High is now Lusher.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah on Freret there.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Freret and Asheville.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: That's right behind the school I went to in elementary.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So did you like school?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah. I'm an avid reader. I like reading, I like studying, yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And was there a teacher that comes to mind who took a special interest in you?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Mrs. Burton.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay tell me about her.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: She took an interest in me. She'd seen that, she said I was a "bright star" and she kept me motivated. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time because you have a lot of influences in the neighborhood and by being a bigger kid I didn't like the other kids getting bullied so I stayed in those kind of fights helping the little guy.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: On the outside seeing me fighting you would say, "You're being a bully," but if you looked into it you'll see, "Oh he was helping the little guy," you know and she saw that. She saw that a couple of times that when somebody would go and tell her what the situation would be. She'd go, "There go my little knight in shining armor," and stuff like that so she took a liking to me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What grade was that?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Sixth grade.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is it fair to say I'm going to assume from everything you've said that you grew up knowing that you were loved and cared for and nurtured as opposed to feeling like you kind of have to make it on your own, is that correct?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I can I have a fairly good picture of where you are in your neighborhood but for somebody who's not familiar with the neighborhood, could you describe what they might me seeing if they were on your front doorstep looking out into the neighborhood on a typical afternoon when you were an adolescent?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Around what time? Or around what time of day?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right like five o'clock in the evening.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: School kids playing. Football in the middle of the yard. We might be playing basketball crossing Green School. Just neighborhood stuff like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah it doesn't sound like, from my understanding of that neighborhood, there wasn't a whole lot of drug traffic or any kind of.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No. Not on that side.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah not on that side. Was there fighting in your home?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No. You might have little minor disagreements like any other family but as far as fist fighting, an all-out brawl, no.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. Okay, good. And you explained that there were some fights that were out there and you felt like you needed to kind of stop some of the bullying we got into that. Did you ever get in trouble in school for fighting?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: A lot of times.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And were they the same types of situations?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Situations like that, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And was that the reason you were put out of Cohen you said?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Right. My little brother and another guy had a fight and I stopped them from fighting. I set the little boy to the side and sent my little brother home. Later on, maybe about three weeks later, his older brother saw me after a fight I mean after a dance at Cohen and he said, "Your little brother had a fight with my little brother?"

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I said, "Yeah I stopped them from fighting." This and that.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I knew the guy and before you know it somebody from over there blindsided me. It was a big gang fight there and I end up having to defend myself against maybe a slew of people and that word got back that it was a big gang fight after and I was supposed to have brought a weapon to school and all this kind of stuff and from there my lockers were looked into, everything's investigated. Nothing came of it, but I was sent to another school.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Any issues with the law as you were in school? I know you got kicked out of school for fighting.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No. That's all.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was this the first time you were ever arrested for this particular charge?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I wasn't for this offense that I'm on now? Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That was the first time?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I've been arrested before but this is the first time I've been convicted of anything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were the prior arrests about?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Possession of stolen property, turning around on the lakefront without a driver's license mediocre things like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And what was the highest grade of school that you finished?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Tenth grade.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tenth grade. Why'd you stop?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I started selling drugs and I felt doomed. I looked at my father. My father, who had like a third or fourth grade education, but he ended up going into the military. He ended up having a nice little meager life but I was like, "Okay" But then him and my mother split for some apparent reason. I don't know today why they split and me and a friend of mine got together and I said, "Man I need some help."

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My mother left, took my brothers and sisters, left me with my father. I'm staying there and we don't have anything. She took everything out of the house." He said, "Alright what do you want me to do about that?" I said, "I need some help. I need to get on my feet."

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you end up finding a place on your own?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir. Several. Several houses.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Alright. What about girlfriends?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: How many?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me about that. Did you have anybody in particular stand out in your mind to this day?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Several.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about them.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: You want me to call names?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Benika, Sherry, Denise, and Rochette. Those four.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. They still hold a special place in your mind.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have children with any of them?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Sherry.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How many kids?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: One daughter.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about your daughter.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Man. The joy of my life. I met her at the rodeo ground in person but I had been writing her since the day she was born. She was born three days after I was convicted.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: So I've been writing little notes, sending little cards for every little occasion, every little situation all the way up 'til she was the age sixteen. Her mother brought her to the rodeo. I don't know why to this day why she would never bring her--today she's not even on my visiting list. But at the rodeo ground, somebody tapped me on my shoulder and I turn around I say, "Yes how're you doing?"

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: "Somebody would like to meet you," says another little girl who happens to be her sister. I said, "Who?" "That girl over there" "How're you doing?" And I went back to cooking cause that's what I do out there on the rodeo ground and she said, "You know a girl named Trishell?" and it [gestures an explosion]. Oh man that just blew me away, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sixteen?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Sixteen.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Does she look like you?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I wish she's in my pictures, yes. You can look at it later.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. How's that relationship been since then?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Man she writes me on the kiosk machine. I don't call but I use the kiosk machine to communicate with her.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old is she now?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: She will be twenty-six November the 8th.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And since then, since you were sixteen you've managed to keep a relationship going?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Oh yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: And she's always writing me about any type of situation she's in and questioning me about anything. And we have what is called 'real talk sessions.' I want you to talk to me about anything, I don't care what it is, whatever the situation may be, I want you to be able to communicate with me because I want you to learn from my mistakes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are you a grandfather now?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is she in New Orleans?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes. She's in Metairie now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Cool.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: She runs her own nursery which makes me very proud of her. She went to college and everything. She completed college. She went to De La Salle and she's running her own makeup thing. She's trying to do the, not Kim Kardashian, the other sister...one of the Kardashians. She's doing the same thing as the Kardashians sister.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Kylie.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I have no idea.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I just read about it. I said, "That's what she's doing!" So she's real successful in that area.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's great. And De La Salle, that's a good school she went to. So her mother must have been doing something right?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you manage to stay in touch with her?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Off and on, yes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright so who comes to visit you up here now?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So it's mainly you're communication with folks outside.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Just through the kiosk machine.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Through the kiosk machine.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Basically. Now I work the visiting shed. One of the things I do like I was telling you earlier.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You cook, right?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah I cook so that's another area I cook in. My job right now is at the front gate where I cook at the Big House Cafe. That's one of my major passions.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and tell me about that. What do you cook? What do you like to cook?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Anything. I like to get in there and just.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so if I wanted to have one of your signature dishes, what would it be?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Well I like chicken breast parmesan over rotini.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. What do you cook at the rodeo?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Chicken breast, we do chicken strips, fries, just quick little meals.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Well I'll come find you at the rodeo next month.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Got your mouth watering!

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You've got me thinking about food. Drugs and alcohol, while you were also while you were dealing drugs as a source to get income, was it a part of your own lifestyle at all?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No, I've never used drugs. It was just a means of.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So let me ask you this. It's kind of a 'What if?' question. So let's say this charge didn't come into your life, how do you imagine the rest of it would have gone? What would you be doing?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I like the bodyguard. I liked that. I liked docking ship because it took me away from the neighborhood. Both of them took me away from the neighborhood. Being able to help people that was one of my major things.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I want to get into looking at the impacts of what happened were on your family and how you've been managing that and get into the Angola part of your life, but before I do that is there something if I really want to understand who you are as a person from your childhood experiences.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is there something that I didn't ask you about coming up that really has sort of defined who you are, something that I should have? We covered quite a lot of things but I just want to, before I move on, give you the chance address anything that I missed.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Not right now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sounds good. So Angola. Do you remember the bus ride from Hunt?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir. I remember the bus ride from the New Orleans Parish Prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How was the parish prison experience?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Typical jail scene.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How long were you in there through the trial?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: From April 1st to December 10th.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So not that long actually. And then you go to Hunt for classification. Tell me what's going through your head as you're riding down Tunica Hills.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: "What the hell I done got myself into? What they threw me away because I'm so far away from home I don't know where I'm at." Like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were you scared?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes. When you first come to prison you've got a little anxiety about who may want to try you but again I always lived with the confidence that my reputation precedes me and I know what I look like, I'm not somebody you really want to mess with so I have that understanding. But after that I had my first altercation here and after that--a long time and I didn't have any more problems.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. That's a very common theme that if someone's going to try you to see if you're going to fight.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Or run, whatever one that you're going to do. But fear is a part of both of those issues like you just finished asking me. Either you're going to run or you're going to stand and fight. Which one you want to use?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself getting into disciplinary issues with security when you first got here?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Well I have 58 write ups all together.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Are most of those clustered around the first few years you were here?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: A majority of them, yes. The last one I had was in the last three years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was three years ago?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And were most of those defiance?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Some of them. The majority of them was I had this attitude I'd felt like I'd been thrown away. I'm not hearing from my family. Everybody you just like disown me like y'all know I'm not guilty of this particular situation, why are y'all just so when I see this officer approach me and be abrasive and I'm...by me being a big guy, I learned later, just experience talking now, that some people when they approach you and you're a big person they have to put on a macho thing to show you that they're in control.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: All you've got to do is talk to me and we're going to get a real good understanding, but if you come a certain kind of way then the young immature person that I was snaps. Yeah all it took was a little bit and if I felt like you was slighting me in any kind of way especially the way the prison was then you couldn't allow anybody. I don't care who it was.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Because it's just a sign of weakness.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So obviously you're a very different person now twenty-six years later. Before we get there can you take a minute to describe the Juan Matthews, the twenty-one year old Juan Matthews?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Who? Beaver?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah tell me about Beaver who came in here.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My father nicknamed me Beaver because he said I stayed busy as a beaver and beaver's stood and that's basically still my regiment now as you can see I'm everywhere cooking. I'm always doing something positive. I'm always on the move.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: When I first came here, that character was low tolerant. If you showed me any type of form of stupidity, I can understand and see ignorance, but stupidity, if you show me that you looking at me a certain kind of way, if you showing me that you trying to play me in any kind of way then I would address it. Whatever kind of way you want to deal with it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How are you different now?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I'm a little more patient now because I understand even the ignorant man as well as the stupid man you've got to give them time because just as I was that way, some people need to grow up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's the difference between ignorant and stupid?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Ignorance you don't know any better. Stupid you know what you're doing, you just decide to just do it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay I got it. That's a good distinction. So you're a trustee.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes sir. Class A trustee.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Class A trustee. You know, clearly proven yourself. In spite of the last write up three years ago, you're obviously given the freedom to move around the prison and cook wherever you are. So what do you think led to the changes?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: It's internal. I think that transformation start from the inside and you grow up. Psychologists say it's, what do you call it, what's the word.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sort of cognitive development?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Menopause, criminal menopause!

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Criminal menopause.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: The criminal menopause aspect of it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Aging out.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah so you get to a certain age like.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You're just done with it.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's a very common thing both in the prison and outside of the prison. I ask you that because sometimes people can point to a specific event, sometimes it's some kind of religious awakening for some people, other times it's a mentor that took interest in them. For you I'm understanding that you're just you're getting tired of it, aging out.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: God has a big part of in my life. I just don't wear it on my sleeve. If it had not been for God's intervention into my affairs in my life, I think it would have been way worse in prison than I probably would have died here quicker than I would have died on the street because I've gotten to this, "I didn't care"

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I mean I think there's also a very special kind of frustration and grief if you're wrongfully convicted. It's just a different thing to wrap your head around.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Especially when you have tight knit family like I come from that once it seems like their support and your expectation of their support is not there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So let's talk a little bit about that. There's obviously the family of the victim in this case. Tell me a little bit about the impact of you being arrested, and charged, and convicted with second degree murder. How did that affect your family?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I think they're ashamed to be affiliated with anything criminal and I think that's the biggest issue. That's why nobody wants to talk about it. Everybody shies away from it. Once I start asking questions, "When are you coming to see me," "When can I get you on the visiting list?" "Why you didn't fill out this form." "Why you didn't," you know then there's a shut down.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: "Look I'm trying to go on the pardon board. I'm trying to do this. I'm trying to do that. I need some assistance." I'm hearing nothing. It's a void. So it's like, "Yeah we believe that you didn't do this, but you Beaver" You know so but I'm not Beaver anymore.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You said that your father passed away within days--

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Thirteen days after I was.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think his death had anything to do with watching you go through this?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I fault myself, yeah. Just being in this whole unfortunate situation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about your mother? How has she fared through all this?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: She's still living. She's in Hahnville, Louisiana. I hear from her periodically but not as much as I would like to. Every now and then I might see her like my daughter's mama she brought her with her to visit me when she brought my daughter one of those times to the rodeo grounds, but other than that no.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you expect to see any of them this October?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: If I'm given the opportunity to go out there. I plan to be out there. One of the guys asked me to change the area to go cook for them. If I'm allowed to go on their concession I will.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you expect that you'll see anybody from your family coming up or is there no plan?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I don't know because it's been a while since I've been out there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Who do you think took it the worst in your family?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: My little sister. My youngest sister. She you can sense it in her letters on the kiosk and when I might talk to her on the telephone. I can't even talk to her now, I don't even have her telephone number.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Why is that?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: It changes. I really stopped pushing people. I learned that if I asking certain questions, I start looking into certain things they back up so I just this is just my little world right here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell me a little bit about some of the organizations that you've been a part of. What have you been doing since you've been here at Angola? Did you finish your GED here?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Yes I have a GED. I have I'm a graduate of Theological Seminary.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I'm a graduate of the cooking school. I'm a graduate of, I got an associate's degree in business. I might have all together six trades and four degrees.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's very impressive.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: And maybe 150 other certificates from various different programs. I created 25 programs.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you've been busy as a beaver.

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: Living up to my nickname.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is that still your nickname?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: No I'm better known as Hakim. I'm a Muslim with the Islamic community.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What led to that?

transcript.speaker: Juan
transcript.content: I was introduced to Islam on the street in 1986 while I was still doing what I was doing. I think that's where the seed was planted it just took a little time for--once you come into prison and you start trying to find a balance. Then I ran through a few of the call outs and then I ended up going to the Islamic call out, then I went to Camp C and me and another guy, John Harris they call him Daylight, new redeem he was real intelligent and it wasn't none of this superficial, superstitious, ignorant belief.

transcript.speaker: Juan
